displayed_text: Family Member: He goes outside. Doctor: Yes. He’s got a little color. (Laughs) Patient: If it wasn’t for this darn ankle I’d be… Doctor: I think you know what you need to do about that. You just got to ease up man. Patient: Yeah I do. Yeah. Thank you. God bless you. Family Member: Thank you. Patient: And I think the world of you, this is still rolling. I think the world of you. Doctor: Just say I need a raise. Patient: Send her to Toledo for a vacation. (Laughs) Doctor: Nice. See ya. Patient: Yeah. (Door closes)

Patient: Uh when we had back Monday night. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: We got out of the car, I mean I couldn’t… Doctor: You felt it? Patient: Well I couldn’t step on it. I couldn’t walk up the step normally. I had to take the right leg up and take the right because if I try to go with this it’s just. Doctor: What’d you do in Alabama? Patient: Oh, tailgate with my college football friends. It was homecoming. Doctor: Okay, you’re making me work hard Mr. S____. You know what we have to do? We have to repeat your scans anyways because it’s time. You’re last one was July. Patient: My what scan? Doctor: Your CAT scan/bone scan just to see what’s going on. I’m not sure that the leg’s anything. You know, sometimes it’s a red herring like hey, I’ve been driving and I was partying and then it kind of hurt. We’re always perpetually paranoid about clots. You know that. Any type of blood clot. But I don’t think you have that because normally it shows up in our lower legs and our calves and your calves are as skinny as they come so and they don’t hurt and they’re not swollen so we’ll leave it there. But that leg, you know, we always have to fuss about because we know your bone scan can change at any time. I know we finished chemo but it might be time to figure out what else is happening. You look great so I’m thrilled about that but I also don’t want to just rely on the PSA and whatever to see what’s happening so CAT scan, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Patient: Same thing I had before. Doctor: And bone scan, same thing. Now, let’s fast forward so we don’t freak out that if it’s worse, and you know my definition of worse is not the stuff went away that’s back, it’s just do I see more things or black spots on your bone scan. Your bone scan doesn’t changed much as you know. It kind of looks perpetually icky based on your original so you haven’t changed this whole time. I’m looking to see if there’s new spots in the leg or anywhere else. Now that I know you have pain and discomfort there, I of course look there to make sure there is nothing new there. Patient: Well, this only started when I…

Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Why do you make me work so hard? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: My brain is on overdrive. Nice to see you both. I’m like racking my brain to see how to move forward and I’m just bummed out that you’re still in pain. Is this right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Same place? Patient: Legs, mostly the legs, a little bit in the back, but I wanted to address the fatigue. That’s really… Doctor: Yeah, you just feel wiped out? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Is that still a reaction from radiation six months ago? Doctor: No. Family Member: No, He shouldn’t have any effects from the radiation at this point? Doctor: No, I mean the only sort of culprit is untreated prostate cancer. You know if I had to sort of go back and we go a round of a bunch of pills

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works. Patient: I see. Doctor: All the things it does downstream without the ball. We’ve been testing that as part of this trial. So I need to dig into the group that’s testing and find out are you one of those guys that was positive? Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you were positive, that would mean pretty strongly that we shouldn’t try more hormone treatments. You need to be positive for that to go on this immune trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh they’re looking for folks who might have more aggressive hormone insensitive cases. So I’m, I’m going to do that this week just to find out.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.10 or more times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::10 or more times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: There you go S___. Doctor: Living is very important but we can't do it with you laid up in bed doing nothing and just say well it's good we got the prostate cancer all taken care of. Family Member: Right that’s not good. Doctor: I say that all the time too. Patient: The one on my ribs doesn't bother me. Doctor: It doesn’t bother you. Patient: That doesn’t bother me. The one that frightens me is the one’s going up and down my spine. Doctor: Yeah, they won't be subtle when they decide to act tough. You're gonna feel it. It's not the occasional, Oh, that kind of hurts. It's the oh man this day hurts every day. Family Member: He has body aches, constantly, his whole body aches and I'm trying to figure out what's causing these body aches. It's like he sat there the other day and was telling me how he was feeling and I know this is terrible, but I started laughing because and I know I was not laughing at you. Yeah, I feel overwhelmed. Like there's nothing I can do. Patient: I’ve been going to a chiropractor for 15 years. Almost on a weekly basis Doctor: Yeah. Patient: To get my back adjusted. They adjust my upper back and my lower back and they adjust my neck. Family Member: But this all over body aching is how long.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Especially, when we are starting you on a medicine that could Patient: Right, can Doctor: Worsen your blood pressure. I may need to adjust it further. Patient: Okay. How about like walking for extended, like, two to three mile walks, is that, is that alright? Doctor: It’s play it by ear as to how much you are hurting. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, I’m planning on getting scans next week and seeing Patient: Okay. Doctor: You anyway. So, within a week or two, I’ll be able to tell you. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: What we are doing. Okay. The Zytiga, now this is a very specialized medication because it’s for cancer. Okay. So, we will need to send it to a mail order pharmacy. There are these specialty pharmacies

Patient: I could use some. I need that what’s it named renewed, too…my benazepril. Remember you renewed that blood pressure pain medicine for me? Doctor: Okay. Patient: I need that, too. I don’t have a primary care doctor right now. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m ‘ppossed to, ‘pposed to go see one of the Wayne State guys next Thursday. Doctor: Yeah, because one day I’m gonna assign you somebody or something, and then your insurance changed? Patient: No, that one over there, I didn’t. That’s why I told them I didn’t want to come back over there no more. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I didn’t… they didn’t impress me. I mean, they fine (laughs) Doctor: Don’t tell me. They didn’t yell at you enough? Doctor: Okay. Patient: It’s south for you and I’m gonna start going there. Doctor: Okay, but I’ll send it in because I don’t want you to run around with high blood pressure either.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But more concerning is just you have more lymph nodes or they’re not even technically lymph nodes they’re more… Patient: Nodules. Doctor: …nodules in the belly whereas before… Doctor: Yeah. It’s more of the schmutz that we talked about… Patient: Um hum. Doctor: …that was hard to characterize. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That schmutz has sort of formalized more into you can call them a nodule, a mass… Patient: Mass. Doctor: …a thingy, a whatever it is, but it’s the cancer. Patient: Mass.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a one month version, we have a three month version, we have a year long version. We could start with the one-month version just to make sure things are okay. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And I could ask my nurse to get authorization for that. So I don’t think we could just give it to you right now. Patient: Right. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think she has to get it improved from you insurance company and then you could come back in a week or two and get it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then you’ll have a consult. Family Member: Mm,hmm.

Family Member: And there’s no other – nothin’ for him. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Besides that. You have something else besides that! You, you have another choice. So, either you try (Pause) Doctor: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Well, it’s a change, you know. It’s just this, this cancer’s just letting you know that it’s doin’ it’s thing every step of the way. You haven’t had two seconds of a break, and it’s hard. And I know one thing you love to do is ride your bike, and it’s hard to do when things aren’t right down there. Whether it’s pain or – Patient: Well, doc, you know -- Doctor: Incontinence or whatever. Patient: Okay. So, no, no. Here, here’s the deal. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Here’s the deal. Okay? (Pause5sec) Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: You follow what I’m sayin’, you know? And I know, you know, time might not be that long. You follow what I’m sayin’? You know?

Family Member: Right. Doctor: So you’re not into it, but it, it just tastes really good. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then there’s the H___ C___, which is also pretty good. Family Member: I’ve heard of it. Okay. Doctor: Right across the street. Family Member: Oh. Patient: You know me better than that. Family Member: Seeing the head doctor. Patient: I’m kind of hanging outside of these. Doctor: Nice. It was good to see you. I’ve got to put up with this all by myself. Family Member: I know. I mean I got a little sick this year, too, so. Didn’t we tell you?

Family Member 1: So we're not starting nothing today. Doctor: No, because this isn't that you know, that oral pill is investigational. So you- the first thing we have to do is have you sign the right papers and make sure that whatever we just discussed, yep, get it get the copy at home, just so everybody's on the same page. Family Member 3: When does it start? Doctor: So we're hoping to start within a couple of weeks or but you know, or even sooner, because there’s that time crunch. Family Member 1: It worries me that, it’s aggressive, his cancer. Doctor: It is. It is. Family Member 1: So with him walking around, not on anything that is upsetting me. Doctor: Of course. Family Member 1: And him too. Patient: So I have to continue the Dexamethasone? Doctor: Yes. For now, until we sort of straighten out the timing Patient: Because I’ll be running out what- next Tuesday? Family Member 1: I’ll call.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know then clearly me telling you you know what things are getting worse just come off this and go get… Patient: Yeah, that’s right. Doctor: Because that would be a really bad outcome overall. Patient: Yeah but it’s not like that so that’s… Doctor: Yeah, that’s a good thing. That’s why we’re having this back and forth even. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it was clear cut growth I’m not gonna keep you on something that’s not helping you. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know I would tell you ditch this and just go get some other treatment. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: So for now we gave you the pills for today. Patient: Right.

Patient: No. I don’t have any. Doctor: Still any numbness around your mouth or-? Patient: A little bit when, you know, coughing. Doctor: So. So how often are you taking the morphine? Patient: About two at night. Doctor: A little, nothing during the day? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. How’s your bowels been? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So slow? That’s what you told me last time. Patient: Yeah, but, you know. Doctor: Still moving daily?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. The prednisone you would stay on because we need it for the chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I think last time we talked a little bit about we have one clinical trial where we are giving men chemotherapy. Huh, that’s the standard. Huh, and then we, huh, ask men to participate and also getting vitamin C. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That’s the experimental part. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Huh, so it really is asking a lot of you to give us extra time to sort out whether giving vitamin C makes a difference. Patient: Okay.
